title: Derby Racecourse Roman settlement
text:
The Derby Racecourse Roman settlement was the third settlement in Derby or Derventio which was a small <a href="town">town</a> in the <a href="Roman%20province">Roman province</a> of <a href="Britannia">Britannia</a>. It lies 600m east of <a href="Derventio%20%28Little%20Chester%29">Derventio fort</a> in <a href="Little%20Chester">Little Chester</a>, on the outskirts of <a href="Derby">Derby</a>, in the English county of <a href="Derbyshire">Derbyshire</a>. The Roman road from Derventio to <a href="Sawley%2C%20Derbyshire">Sawley</a> on the River Trent passes the settlement. It is a scheduled National Monument.
Description.
The first <a href="Roman%20fort">Roman fort</a> in the area was built on the opposite bank of the <a href="River%20Derwent%2C%20Derbyshire">River Derwent</a> at <a href="Strutt%27s%20Park%20Roman%20fort">Strutt's Park</a>. It was replaced about AD 80 by a fort at <a href="Little%20Chester">Little Chester</a>, but this only lasted about forty years, then decommissioned. The fort was later re-occupied and re-used for a further twenty five years then unoccupied until the late 3rd century when a stone wall was built around the town.
There is evidence of extensive Roman activity in Little Chester.
Derby Racecourse Roman settlement site was founded around AD 90. It is considered by <a href="English%20Heritage">English Heritage</a> to be an import example of a fort-vicus. This was a civilian settlement attached to a Roman military fort- in this case <a href="Derventio%20%28Little%20Chester%29">Derventio</a>. It is a mark that the Cornovii tribesmen were accepting the Roman way of life and integrating themselves into the Roman economy- i.e. Romanisation.
Pottery kilns have been discovered dating from AD90 to the mid second century when ironworking took place. The jug illustrated was fired at this settlement and is now in <a href="Derby%20Museum%20and%20Art%20Gallery">Derby Museum</a>. There was also a large cemetery with five stone <a href="mausoleum">mausolea</a>.
History.
This part of Britannica was occupied by a tribe known as the <a href="Cornovii%20%28Midlands%29">Cornovii</a>. In AD 46–47 the Roman Army under the direction of governor <a href="Aulus%20Plautius">Aulius Plautius</a> had probably occupied the lands to the south of the <a href="River%20Trent">River Trent</a>, so in AD 50 this was the front line. There is a shortage of written documentation about these years so reliance is made on archaeological excavations. Late in 47 the new governor of Britain, <a href="Ostorius%20Scapula">Ostorius Scapula</a>, began a campaign against the tribes of modern-day Wales, and the <a href="Cheshire%20Plain">Cheshire Gap</a>. During these times <a href="Strutt%27s%20Park%20Roman%20fort">Strutt's Park Roman fort</a>, was one of the new forts built along the new supply road from <a href="Wroxeter">Wroxeter</a> to <a href="Rossington">Rossington</a>.
The campaign to conquer the <a href="Silures">Silures</a> continued under the governor <a href="Quintus%20Veranius">Quintus Veranius</a> and his successor <a href="Gaius%20Suetonius%20Paulinus">Gaius Suetonius Paulinus</a> but by now Strutt Park's rôle was to maintain the peace. Around AD 74, the lands north of the River Mersey became unstable, when Queen <a href="Cartimandua">Cartimandua</a> had to ask for Roman assistance to fight off a rebellion. Then in AD78, <a href="Gnaeus%20Julius%20Agricola">Gnaeus Julius Agricola</a>, made famous through the highly laudatory biography of him written by his son-in-law, <a href="Tacitus">Tacitus</a>, was made governor. He consolidated the forts, improved the road infrastructure and led some now well documented campaigns- firstly in AD78, he reconquered North Wales, then in AD79 he conquered the <a href="Brigantes">Brigantes</a> and <a href="Parisi%20%28Yorkshire%29">Parisi</a> taking all of Northern England up to the present Scottish border. Strutt's Park fort was vacated in AD 80 when <a href="Derventio%20Coritanorum">Derventio</a> was built.
The Emperor <a href="Hadrian">Hadrian</a> visited Britannia in AD120 and ordered his <a href="Hadrian%27s%20Wall">wall</a> to be built. Though Britannia always had a large garrison, focus now changed to industrial production. Derby produced pottery and had access to the lead mining to the north in the <a href="Peak%20District">Peak District</a>, later it became a centre for metalworking. This continued for the next 200 years.
Excavations.
The site was excavated between 1968 and 1983.
